title: Conductors - conducting sphere w external charge

content.question: A neutral conducting sphere has two points, <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, on its outer surface as shown in the figure. A positively charged metal rod is brought close to the sphere from the left side near Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Which of the following is a correct statement about the electric potential at the two points when the positively charged rod is nearby and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: The electric potential at Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is lower than that at Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because the electrons move freely to be on the side close to the positive object.

The electric potential at Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is lower than that at Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because the protons move freely to be on the side furthest from the positive object.

The electric potential at Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to the potential at Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because the charged sphere is neutral, meaning there are no charges to move around the sphere.

The electric potential at Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to the potential at Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because the sphere is a conductor so its surface must be an equipotential surface.

content.answer: The electric potential at Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to the potential at Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because the sphere is a conductor so its surface must be an equipotential surface.
